volsense_core.models package

Submodules

volsense_core.models.garch_methods module

class ARCHForecaster(config: GARCHConfig | None = None, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: object

Thin, safe wrapper around arch.arch_model supporting GARCH, EGARCH, and GJR.

Usage

>>> cfg = GARCHConfig(model="gjr", p=1, o=1, q=1, dist="t")
>>> f = ARCHForecaster(cfg).fit(ret)          # ret: pd.Series or np.array
>>> sigma_next = f.predict(horizon=5)         # np.ndarray length 5 (annualized by default)
>>> roll = f.rolling_forecast(ret)            # DataFrame with one-step-ahead forecasts
fit(returns: ndarray | Series | Iterable[float]) → ARCHForecaster[source]

Fit the selected ARCH-family model to a return series.

Parameters:

returns (ArrayLike) – Daily simple returns (e.g., price.pct_change()).

Returns:

Self, with fitted result accessible via .result.

Return type:

ARCHForecaster

get_config() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get a dictionary copy of the current configuration.

Returns:

Configuration as a plain dictionary.

Return type:

dict

predict(horizon: int | list[int] = 1) → ndarray[source]

Generate multi-horizon volatility forecasts.

Parameters:

horizon (int or list[int]) – Single horizon or list of horizons to forecast (e.g., 1 or [1, 5, 10]).

Raises:

RuntimeError – If called before fit() (via the .result accessor).

Returns:

Forecasted sigma values (annualized if configured), shape (len(horizons),).

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

property result

Access the underlying ARCHModelResult after fit().

Raises:

RuntimeError – If the model has not been fitted yet.

Returns:

Fitted result object from arch.

Return type:

object

rolling_forecast(returns: ndarray | Series | Iterable[float], start: int | None = None, min_obs: int | None = None, refit_every: int = 1) → Series | ndarray[source]

Produce rolling one-step-ahead forecasts using an expanding window.

Parameters:

  • returns (ArrayLike) – Daily simple returns. If a Series is provided, output is a Series aligned to input dates.

  • start (int, optional) – First index to start forecasting. Defaults to max(p+q+o, 30) if None.

  • min_obs (int, optional) – Minimum observations before first fit; overrides start when provided.

  • refit_every (int) – Refit frequency in steps (1 = refit each step).

Raises:

ValueError – If there are fewer than ~50 observations.

Returns:

One-step-ahead sigma forecasts (annualized if configured), as Series or ndarray.

Return type:

pandas.Series or numpy.ndarray

class GARCHConfig(model: str = 'garch', p: int = 1, q: int = 1, o: int = 0, dist: str = 'normal', mean: str = 'Zero', scale: float = 100.0, annualize: bool = True, fit_kwargs: Dict[str, Any] = None)[source]

Bases: object

Configuration for ARCH-family forecasters.

Parameters:

  • model (str) – Model family to use: ‘garch’ (GARCH), ‘egarch’ (EGARCH), or ‘gjr’ (GJR/TGARCH).

  • p (int) – ARCH order.

  • q (int) – GARCH order.

  • o (int) – Asymmetry order (used for GJR when > 0). Ignored for EGARCH.

  • dist (str) – Innovation distribution, e.g., ‘normal’, ‘t’, ‘skewt’, or ‘ged’.

  • mean (str) – Mean model, typically ‘Zero’ for daily returns.

  • scale (float) – Factor to scale returns before fitting (e.g., 100.0 for percent returns).

  • annualize (bool) – If True, convert daily sigma to annualized volatility using sqrt(252).

  • fit_kwargs (dict, optional) – Extra keyword arguments passed to arch’s .fit() (e.g., {‘disp’: ‘off’}).

Raises:

ValueError – If an unsupported model name is provided.

annualize: bool = True
dist: str = 'normal'
fit_kwargs: Dict[str, Any] = None
mean: str = 'Zero'
model: str = 'garch'
o: int = 0
p: int = 1
q: int = 1
scale: float = 100.0
fit_arch(returns: ndarray | Series | Iterable[float], model_type: str = 'garch', dist: str = 'normal', p: int = 1, q: int = 1, o: int = 0, mean: str = 'Zero', scale: float = 100.0, annualize: bool = True, **fit_kwargs)[source]

Quick-fit a GARCH/EGARCH/GJR model and return the fitted result.

Parameters:

  • returns (ArrayLike) – Daily simple returns to fit on.

  • model_type (str) – Model family: ‘garch’, ‘egarch’, or ‘gjr’.

  • dist (str) – Innovation distribution, e.g., ‘normal’, ‘t’, ‘skewt’, ‘ged’.

  • p (int) – ARCH order.

  • q (int) – GARCH order.

  • o (int) – Asymmetry order (GJR) when > 0; ignored for EGARCH.

  • mean (str) – Mean model, typically ‘Zero’ for daily returns.

  • scale (float) – Factor to scale returns before fitting.

  • annualize (bool) – If True, annualize sigma via sqrt(252).

  • fit_kwargs (dict) – Extra keyword args forwarded to arch .fit().

Returns:

Fitted ARCH model result object.

Return type:

object

forecast_arch(fitted_model, horizon: int = 1, scale: float = 100.0, annualize: bool = True)[source]

Generate volatility forecasts from a fitted ARCHModelResult.

Parameters:

  • fitted_model (object) – Result object returned by arch after fitting.

  • horizon (int) – Number of steps to forecast ahead.

  • scale (float) – Scale factor used during fitting to unscale sigma.

  • annualize (bool) – If True, annualize sigma via sqrt(252).

Returns:

Array of forecasted sigma values of length horizon.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

standardize_outputs(dates, tickers, forecast_vols, realized_vols=None, model_name='UnknownModel', horizons=None)[source]

Standardize model outputs for evaluation/backtesting.

Parameters:

  • dates (list or numpy.ndarray) – Forecast or validation dates.

  • tickers (list or numpy.ndarray) – Corresponding tickers for each row.

  • forecast_vols (numpy.ndarray) – Predicted volatilities, shape (N, H) or (N,).

  • realized_vols (numpy.ndarray or list, optional) – True realized volatilities, same shape as forecast_vols.

  • model_name (str) – Model identifier, e.g., ‘BaseLSTM’, ‘GlobalVolForecaster’, ‘ARCHForecaster’.

  • horizons (list[int], optional) – Forecast horizons, e.g., [1, 5, 10]. Defaults to 1..H if None.

Returns:

DataFrame with columns [‘date’,’ticker’,’horizon’,’forecast_vol’,’realized_vol’,’model’].

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

volsense_core.models.global_vol_forecaster module

class FeatureDropout(p: float)[source]

Bases: Module

Channel-wise (feature) dropout: same mask for all time-steps.

forward(x: Tensor) → Tensor[source]

Apply channel-wise dropout to inputs.

Parameters:

x (torch.Tensor) – Input tensor of shape [B, W, F].

Returns:

Tensor with dropped feature channels, scaled by 1/(1-p) during training.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class GlobalVolForecaster(n_tickers: int, window: int, n_horizons: int | list, emb_dim: int, hidden_dim: int, num_layers: int, dropout: float, attention: bool = True, residual_head: bool = True, input_size: int | None = None, use_layernorm: bool = True, separate_heads: bool = True, feat_dropout_p: float = 0.1, variational_dropout_p: float = 0.1)[source]

Bases: Module

Global sequence model for multi-ticker, multi-horizon volatility forecasting.

Combines LSTM backbone, optional temporal self-attention, per-horizon heads, and optional residual head. Ticker identity is injected via learned embeddings.

forward(tkr_id: Tensor, X: Tensor) → Tensor[source]

Forward pass.

Parameters:

  • tkr_id (torch.Tensor) – Integer ticker IDs of shape [B].

  • X (torch.Tensor) – Input features of shape [B, W, F] (or [B, F], which will be unsqueezed).

Returns:

Horizon outputs of shape [B, H] (or [B] when H==1).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class TrainConfig(window: int = 30, horizons: int | list = 1, stride: int = 2, val_start: str = '2025-01-01', val_end: str | None = None, val_mode: str = 'causal', embargo_days: int = 0, target_col: str = 'realized_vol_log', extra_features: list | None = None, epochs: int = 20, lr: float = 0.0003, batch_size: int = 256, device: str = 'cpu', dropout: float = 0.3, use_layernorm: bool = True, separate_heads: bool = True, attention: bool = True, residual_head: bool = True, feat_dropout_p: float = 0.1, variational_dropout_p: float = 0.1, loss_horizon_weights: list | None = None, dynamic_window_jitter: int = 0, grad_clip: float = 1.0, cosine_schedule: bool = True, cosine_restarts: bool = True, oversample_high_vol: bool = False, use_ema: bool = True, ema_decay: float = 0.995, early_stop: bool = True, patience: int = 7, min_delta: float = 0.0, num_workers: int = 0, pin_memory: bool = False)[source]

Bases: object

Training configuration for GlobalVolForecaster.

Parameters:

  • window (int) – Rolling lookback window length (timesteps).

  • horizons (int or list[int]) – Forecast horizons; either an int (max horizon) or explicit list (e.g., [1,5,10]).

  • stride (int) – Step size between training samples (larger reduces overlap).

  • val_start (str) – Validation window start date (inclusive).

  • val_end (str, optional) – Optional validation window end date (exclusive). If None, uses all data after val_start.

  • val_mode (str) – Validation mode; “causal” (train strictly before val_start) or “holdout_slice”.

  • embargo_days (int) – Days excluded on both sides of validation slice in holdout mode.

  • target_col (str) – Target column name (typically realized_vol_log).

  • extra_features (list[str], optional) – Additional feature column names to include beyond “return”.

  • epochs (int) – Number of training epochs.

  • lr (float) – Learning rate for optimizer.

  • batch_size (int) – Mini-batch size.

  • device (str) – Compute device (“cpu” or “cuda”).

  • dropout (float) – Inter-layer dropout probability in the LSTM and heads.

  • use_layernorm (bool) – Whether to apply LayerNorm to the backbone output.

  • separate_heads (bool) – If True, use independent heads per horizon; else a single multi-output head.

  • attention (bool) – If True, apply a MultiheadAttention layer over LSTM outputs.

  • residual_head (bool) – If True, add a residual linear head to improve gradient flow.

  • feat_dropout_p (float) – Channel-wise (feature) dropout probability at input.

  • variational_dropout_p (float) – Variational (time-consistent) input dropout probability.

  • loss_horizon_weights (list[float], optional) – Optional per-horizon loss weights.

  • dynamic_window_jitter (int) – Random jitter (+/-) applied to window size during training.

  • grad_clip (float) – Gradient norm clip value; set None/0 to disable.

  • cosine_schedule (bool) – Use cosine LR schedule.

  • cosine_restarts (bool) – Use cosine schedule with warm restarts (SGDR).

  • oversample_high_vol (bool) – Deprecated knob; kept for compatibility.

  • use_ema (bool) – Maintain an exponential moving average (EMA) of model weights.

  • ema_decay (float) – EMA decay factor in (0,1).

  • early_stop (bool) – Enable early stopping on validation loss.

  • patience (int) – Epochs to wait without improvement before stopping.

  • min_delta (float) – Minimum improvement in validation loss to reset patience.

  • num_workers (int) – DataLoader workers.

  • pin_memory (bool) – DataLoader pin_memory flag.

attention: bool = True
batch_size: int = 256
cosine_restarts: bool = True
cosine_schedule: bool = True
device: str = 'cpu'
dropout: float = 0.3
dynamic_window_jitter: int = 0
early_stop: bool = True
ema_decay: float = 0.995
embargo_days: int = 0
epochs: int = 20
extra_features: list | None = None
feat_dropout_p: float = 0.1
grad_clip: float = 1.0
horizons: int | list = 1
loss_horizon_weights: list | None = None
lr: float = 0.0003
min_delta: float = 0.0
num_workers: int = 0
oversample_high_vol: bool = False
patience: int = 7

target_col: str = 'realized_vol_log'

use_layernorm: bool = True
val_end: str | None = None
val_mode: str = 'causal'
val_start: str = '2025-01-01'
variational_dropout_p: float = 0.1
window: int = 30

build_global_splits(df: DataFrame, cfg: TrainConfig)[source]

Build per-ticker scaled datasets and temporal train/validation splits.

Performs per-ticker StandardScaler fitting on features, maps tickers to IDs, and constructs Dataset objects that emit (ticker_id, windowed features, targets).

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – Input long-form DataFrame with columns [‘date’,’ticker’, cfg.target_col, ‘return’, …].

  • cfg (TrainConfig) – Training configuration with window, horizons, validation window, and feature list.

Raises:

KeyError – If required columns are missing from df.

Returns:

(train_dataset, val_dataset, ticker_to_id, scalers)

Return type:

tuple[torch.utils.data.Dataset, torch.utils.data.Dataset, dict[str,int], dict[str,StandardScaler]]

clone_model_like(model: Module) → Module[source]

Create a non-trainable copy of a model for EMA tracking.

Parameters:

model (torch.nn.Module) – Source model to clone.

Returns:

Cloned model with requires_grad=False for all parameters.

Return type:

torch.nn.Module

make_last_windows(df: DataFrame, window: int)[source]

Extract the last window timesteps per ticker for inference.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – Feature DataFrame with [‘ticker’,’date’, <features…>] sorted by date within ticker.

  • window (int) – Number of trailing rows to keep per ticker.

Returns:

Concatenated DataFrame of last windows for all tickers.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

predict_next_day(model, df_last_windows, ticker_to_id, scalers, window, device='cpu', show_progress=True)[source]

Predict next-day (multi-horizon) volatility for each ticker using the latest window.

Aligns inference features to the per-ticker scaler schema (fills missing features with 0, drops extras), scales inputs, runs the model, and returns a tidy table.

Parameters:

  • model (torch.nn.Module) – Trained GlobalVolForecaster.

  • df_last_windows (pandas.DataFrame) – DataFrame with the most recent window per ticker; must include [‘ticker’,’date’, <features>].

  • ticker_to_id (dict[str, int]) – Mapping from ticker symbol to integer ID used by the model.

  • scalers (dict[str, StandardScaler]) – Per-ticker fitted StandardScaler objects (from training).

  • window (int) – Window length used during training (for validation of shapes).

  • device (str) – Compute device for inference (‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’).

  • show_progress (bool) – Show a tqdm progress bar during prediction.

Returns:

DataFrame with [‘ticker’,’horizon’,’forecast_vol_scaled’].

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

train_global_model(df: DataFrame, cfg: TrainConfig)[source]

Train GlobalVolForecaster end-to-end and return artifacts.

Includes optional cosine scheduling with restarts, EMA tracking, gradient clipping, early stopping, and horizon-weighted MSE.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – Input DataFrame containing [‘date’,’ticker’,’return’, cfg.target_col, …].

  • cfg (TrainConfig) – Training configuration.

Returns:

Tuple of (model, history, val_loader, ticker_to_id, scalers, features).

Return type:

tuple[torch.nn.Module, dict[str, list[float]], torch.utils.data.DataLoader, dict[str,int], dict[str,StandardScaler], list[str]]

update_ema(ema: Module, model: Module, decay: float)[source]

Update EMA model weights and buffers from a source model.

Parameters:

  • ema (torch.nn.Module) – EMA model to be updated in-place.

  • model (torch.nn.Module) – Source model providing current parameters/buffers.

  • decay (float) – EMA decay factor in (0,1); closer to 1 gives slower updates.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

volsense_core.models.lstm_forecaster module

class BaseLSTM(input_dim: int, hidden_dim: int = 128, num_layers: int = 3, dropout: float = 0.2, n_horizons: int = 1, use_layernorm: bool = True, use_attention: bool = True, feat_dropout_p: float = 0.1, residual_head: bool = True, output_activation: str = 'none')[source]

Bases: Module

LSTM-based multi-horizon forecaster with optional self-attention and residual head.

Input: (B, W, F) where W=window, F=features Output: (B, H) where H=len(horizons)

forward(x: Tensor) → Tensor[source]

Forward pass through feature-dropout, LSTM, optional attention, and heads.

Parameters:

x (torch.Tensor) – Input tensor of shape [B, W, F].

Returns:

Predictions of shape [B, H] (or [B] when H==1).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class MultiVolDataset(df: DataFrame, cfg: TrainConfig, scaler: TorchStandardScaler = None)[source]

Bases: Dataset

Windowed multi-horizon dataset for single- or multi-ticker realized vol data.

Expected columns in df:

[“date”, “ticker”, <features…>, target_col]

Behavior:

  • Sorts by (ticker, date)

  • Standardizes features with StandardScaler (train fit, val transform)

  • Standardizes target using train set y_mean/y_std; reuses for val

  • Drops constant features to avoid StandardScaler NaNs

  • Builds rolling windows of length cfg.window with multi-horizon labels

class TrainConfig(window: int = 30, horizons: List[int] = None, val_start: str = None, target_col: str = 'realized_vol', extra_features: list[str] | None = None, batch_size: int = 128, epochs: int = 15, lr: float = 0.0005, weight_decay: float = 1e-05, device: str = 'cpu', dropout: float = 0.2, hidden_dim: int = 128, num_layers: int = 3, use_layernorm: bool = True, use_attention: bool = True, feat_dropout_p: float = 0.1, residual_head: bool = True, output_activation: str = 'none', num_workers: int = 0, pin_memory: bool = False)[source]

Bases: object

Training configuration for BaseLSTM.

Parameters:

  • window (int) – Rolling lookback window length (timesteps).

  • horizons (list[int]) – Forecast horizons (e.g., [1, 5, 10]).

  • val_start (str) – Validation set start date (inclusive, YYYY-MM-DD).

  • target_col (str) – Target column name to predict.

  • extra_features (list[str], optional) – Additional feature names beyond ‘return’ to include.

  • batch_size (int) – Mini-batch size for DataLoader.

  • epochs (int) – Number of training epochs.

  • lr (float) – Learning rate.

  • weight_decay (float) – L2 weight decay.

  • device (str) – Compute device (‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’).

  • dropout (float) – Dropout probability used in model modules.

  • hidden_dim (int) – LSTM hidden size.

  • num_layers (int) – Number of stacked LSTM layers.

  • use_layernorm (bool) – Whether to apply LayerNorm to LSTM outputs.

  • use_attention (bool) – Whether to apply self-attention over LSTM outputs.

  • feat_dropout_p (float) – Feature-wise dropout probability at input.

  • residual_head (bool) – Whether to add a residual linear projection to outputs.

  • output_activation (str) – Output activation (‘none’ | ‘softplus’ | ‘relu’).

  • num_workers (int) – DataLoader workers.

  • pin_memory (bool) – DataLoader pin_memory flag.

batch_size: int = 128

epochs: int = 15

collate_with_dates(batch)[source]

Collate function that stacks tensors and keeps Python datetime objects as a list.

Parameters:

batch (list[tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor, pandas.Timestamp]]) – Iterable of (X, y, date) triplets produced by the Dataset.

Returns:

Tuple of stacked tensors and a list of dates: (X_batch, y_batch, dates).

Return type:

tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor, list]

evaluate_baselstm(model: Module, loader: DataLoader, cfg: TrainConfig, device: str = 'cpu')[source]

Evaluate model on a DataLoader and return de-standardized arrays.

If cfg contains y_mean/y_std (set during training), both predictions and targets are transformed back to the original volatility scale.

Parameters:

  • model (torch.nn.Module) – Trained PyTorch model to evaluate.

  • loader (torch.utils.data.DataLoader) – DataLoader providing batches from the evaluation split.

  • cfg (TrainConfig) – Training config containing target standardization stats.

  • device (str) – Compute device for inference (‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’).

Returns:

Tuple of (preds, actuals) each shaped (N, H).

Return type:

tuple[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray]

train_baselstm(df: DataFrame, cfg: TrainConfig)[source]

Train the BaseLSTM model and return the model, history, and loaders.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – Input feature DataFrame with required columns and target.

  • cfg (TrainConfig) – Training configuration.

Returns:

Tuple (model, history, (train_loader, val_loader)).

Return type:

tuple[torch.nn.Module, dict[str, list[float]], tuple[torch.utils.data.DataLoader, torch.utils.data.DataLoader]]
